title: RCA video output to VGA input.
content:
Hello, I, yet again, have another technical question to petition to the Public Commander Keen Forum. I'm asking here because well... Probably SOMEONE here knows how to help me.

I am looking for a way to convert, as the title said, a standard RCA Plug [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RCA_connector]en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RCA_connector [/url] (The yellow video one.) to a standard VGA output. [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VGA_connector]en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VGA_connector[/url]

Why do I want to do this? Well simple. I HATE USING MY TV to display Oblivion. I would LOVE to output the NTSC signal to my 21 inch CRT moniter that is capable of 1600 x 1200 resolution.

I know that the XBox 360 is capable of rendering at 640x480 (NTSC output standard for videogame consoles. All the way back to PS1 which used 320x200/240? for most games but also could display 640x480 as is the case with Chrono Cross.) 1280720 resolution (720 HD standard) or 19201080 (1080 HD standard)

Honestly... I don't know how those work directly with the RCA connector its self but I DO know that is the only connector that came with my 360. I am sick and tired of useing a fuzzy TV screen to display my games which I KNOW can be displayed at a VERY high resolution, and good frame rate when I have a good quality computer moniter RIGHT in front of me. I am asking specifically how to go from an RCA plug to VGA because if I can get a device to do this for me I can then hook up ALL my consoles to the computer screen. (NES, PS1, Gamecube etc. etc.)

Although if this is impossible my second question is "How do I get my 360 SPECIFICALLY to output to a standard computer moniter." Because lets face it, Bio Shock deserves more than 500-some lines of resolution. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-rolleyes.gif[/img]

I know most of you are thinking, "Why don't you get a gaming computer?"

Well first I already HAVE a GOOD computer (A pentium 3 - 900 MHZ which, quite frankly, keeps par and sometimes SURPASSES in speed in both Windows GUI and rendering with some single core Pentium 4s. No lie. It is an excellent system especially considering its age.) and second I had a choice of paying 1000+ USD for a new computer vs 300 USD for a X-Box 360.

Third... I just want to know how to do this. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]

So yeah... any help OR suggestion I would LOVE to hear. It could be anything from a third party device to having to get a new videocard. (If anyone knows of a PCI video card that has this kind of input let me know because I already have my AGP port taken up by a nice card.) Heck... if you can give me directions on splicing the WIRES I'm down for that. (Already done that so much in the past.)

So yeah... um... -Gal out.-----------------------

title: Re: RCA video output to VGA input.
content:
Splicing wires unfortunately won't work in this case, because a computer monitor has five separate inputs: red, green, blue, horizontal sync and vertical sync. In an RCA plug all five signals are mashed together on the same wire. In a monitor all these signals are separate (which is why there are so many pins in a VGA connector - and my 21" CRT actually has five RCA plugs on the back to accept a signal that's been separated out into individual wires.)

This means that you need to get a device to convert the RCA signal (or "composite" as it's known) into VGA, or "RGBHV" as that's known. Composite to RGBHV converters are probably not that hard to find, you can probably pick up a cheap one on eBay. You have to be careful though, because some just convert the bare signal so for NTSC the monitor ends up seeing a 30Hz signal - and given that the minimum refresh rate for a monitor is 60Hz, it'll appear like you're sitting in front of a strobe light because of the flicker - assuming your monitor even accepts the signal, most just say "signal out of range" because it's too low. You need to get a converter that at least doubles the refresh rate.

The main problem of course is that your monitor may be able to display 1600x1200, but the composite/RCA signal is only 720x576 tops. So even if you do display the image on a computer monitor, it won't be any sharper - in fact it'll probably look worse than on the TV for various reasons.

This is fine if all you want is to use one display device for everything, and for older consoles that aren't capable of anything more, but for something like an XBox that's capable of HDTV, you're far better off buying a proper XBox adapter to output RGBHV signals. This replaces the low-res RCA connector with a different connector, rather than converting it. I'm not sure whether you can get an XBox RGBHV output option, but given that you can connect it to HDTV I'd be surprised if you can't. It may be in the form of a DVI connector, so providing the DVI connector supports DVI-A (analogue RGB over the DVI connector) then you can get a DVI -> HD15 converter which just connects the VGA pins to the proper DVI ones.

This all assumes you've got some way of unplugging your monitor and plugging it into something else, which would be a hassle if you haven't got a KVM you could use. You may want to investigate alternatives, like analogue TV capture cards, which will take an RCA video signal and either record it to disk or display it in a window on the computer screen (which you can make full-screen, just like any other video you watch on a PC.) You do have to be wary with that though, because depending on the card you choose there'll be a lag when the video is encoded and another lag when it's decoded again to be displayed on the screen. This is no problem when watching video, but when you're playing an interactive game you don't want to fire a gun and have to wait a second or two before you see it happen on-screen. Of course cards to do this are a dime a dozen on eBay, so even if it doesn't work out it's unlikely to be an expensive experiment.

Anyway, hopefully this gives you something to go on...![url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: RCA video output to VGA input.
content:
That's interesting - if I use my camera to pass through data over firewire there's a lag of about 200 milliseconds - enough that if I wave my hand in front of the camera you can see it's slightly delayed on screen. Of course that little delay might not be a big issue for gaming, it's probably an individual preference.

If you want a rough idea of the quality you can expect from capturing composite video, take a screenshot, resize it down to about 512x384 and then enlarge it to 768x576 - that's assuming PAL, NTSC is lower again. Personally I think US$40 is a bargain for the improvement in quality you'll get by going native VGA the whole way.

I've got a couple of TV capture cards, one is built into a PCI digital TV tuner card, and the other one I pulled out of a PC in a dumpster one day. I've only ever used the dumpster one just to see if it worked (which it did) but once I saw the quality coming out of it I never bothered again...[url=http://www.shikadi.net/keenwiki/]KeenWiki[/url] | [url=http://www.shikadi.net/moddingwiki/]ModdingWiki[/url]

title: Re: RCA video output to VGA input.
content:
Does it have five BNC plugs? If it does it's unlikely to support composite video, you need an adapter to split the normal VGA connector into five BNC plugs. Both my monitors have this, and I had to use it because running them at 1600x1200@85Hz through the normal VGA connector caused noticeable ghosting.

It won't accept a normal composite/RCA signal though.
